prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Docket conditions

para.paratext: The condition of the calendars of various potential transferee judges may be of interest to the Panel, and counsel may properly provide this information to the Panel. Just as overall docket conditions may be relevant to evaluation of various potential transferee districts,[1] similar information related to each judge's docket may be considered by the Panel.[2] Because that information is not readily available in published form, it may be more difficult to collect and present the information on potential transferee judges to the Panel in a meaningful way.

Caseload and docket conditions may be the most important factor in selecting a judge to be assigned to the litigation. If there is a clearly preferable transferee district, then caseload concerns may be the primary reason for assigning a judge from another district to hear the transferred cases.[3] The Panel often looks at the issue through the lens of overall availability of “time and experience” for the litigation.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

The use of this information in the selection of a transferee district is discussed in § 6:17. Statistical information on the docket conditions in each federal district court is contained in Appendix B and on the Panel's website, http://www.jpml.uscourts.gov/.

See In re American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co. Retiree Benefits “ERISA” Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transferee judge has “favorable caseload burden”); In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (judge has capacity); In re Aimster Copyright Litigation, 177 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2001).
